text: To wait all of these years for a part two this seemed sloppy and rushed they made the bad guy impossible to take down without taking venom away !!??? Would’ve made a good series to continue was okay to watch but the whole movie was them running the whole movie ,just to still die

Despite the thin plot, Venom: The Last Dance surprises with awesome effects and memorable characters. As a MCU And Marvel Comics fan, seeing other symbiontes fighting together to help eachother was truly healing. The action is amazing, and such a good acting job by Tom Hardy.
Good not mind blowing.
Some side story-lines are very boring, but the rest is nice. Alright action.

They tried too much with this movie. Some parts were too long or too short or just not needed. The ending was just blah. It had some great parts that made the movie good, but it's not a movie I wish to watch again.

Venom: The Last Dance was the cinematic equivalent of a stalemate – it didn't particularly impress or disappoint. While it had some neat visuals, the overall experience felt like more of the same old Venom shtick, with a forced Spider-Man: No Way Home tie-in that only served to whet fans' appetites without delivering any real substance. Typical Sony.

Grading: C-
Em minha opinião Venom 3 é um filme que em geral é divertido e condizente com seus antecessores
Venom to me is someone special, and I actually like him, but what he did at the end, was sad but he saved the universe.

This is a very entertaining movie. For me, certainly the best of the trilogy.
They are all amazing just amazing and the comedy in this one is wow

Venom: The Last Dance delivers energetic chaos but falters with a cluttered, unfocused narrative that dims its trilogy-ending potential. While Tom Hardy’s Eddie-Venom duo sparkles with humor, the script overloads with disjointed subplots—blackmail, betrayals, alien swarms—that muddy the stakes. Pacing stumbles in a sluggish second act, and supporting characters like Chiwetel Ejiofor’s Strickland and Juno Temple’s Paine feel like afterthoughts, lacking depth. Andy Serkis’s Knull, despite cosmic promise, is undercooked, and the rushed climax fails to land. Compared to Let There Be Carnage’s lean thrills, this 2024 finale sacrifices coherence for spectacle, missing a chance to elevate the symbiote saga into something truly epic.

Traveling to NYC to clear his name Eddie Brock (Tom Hardy) and his symbiote (also, Tom Hardy), are chased by troublesome critters.

Despite the uncomfortable tonal shifts I enjoyed this film the most of the trilogy.  I'm not a fan of the comic character and this film didn't improve that opinion.  It's watchable even though it does abandon it's own logic.
Not everyone loves it, I get that. But I thought it was the best of the trilogy.
Worth a watch for the action sequences, symbiote cameos, and genuinely wholesome/endearing moments between characters, even if the villain and his minions are functionally just placeholders.
I watched about 3 minutes of this movie before turning it off. It was clearly made for 10 year olds. Absolutely terrible
the writers forgot what makes the venom movies fun: the relationship between eddie and venom. we focused too much on an unnecessary area 51 plot, and spent no time with our main characters
Wish they had more venom movies, but this is a good end for Tom Hardy’s venom. At least now I can’t wait for Spider-Man and venom to be on the big screen and for Null to be a big threat.
It was okay but wish it was better with a different villain
If I had to rank all 2 venom movies, it would be 2 at the bottom (I hated that one), this one in the middle (it was decent) and 1 as the best (Not a masterpiece, but still my favorite).
